To play the movies properly, where you can get the menus, change the audio/subtitles, etc...
What I did was create an iso for each movie.  Then mount the iso using daemon tools.  Then use a media player that can play bd (I use Corel WinDVD).  From there, it'll play the movies exactly like playing them on a blu ray player

Video and sound are superb! The files play flawlessly with PowerDVD 11, but first you make each of the six folder names smaller. That's all you have to do.

Alright so I just finished d/l'ing this. What exactly am I converting to .iso? I used alcohol120 to convert the entire Phantom Menace folder to a .iso using alcohol120 and tried playing it on corel and powerdvd and it wouldn't play on either, said it was an unsupported format. So I then went and turned just the BDMV folder into an .iso format but I got the same results. So what am I doing wrong?

First off awesome download, nothing short of expected, and everything you can expect from blu rays.  Since this is the first time I downloaded a real blu rays from here I figured best to look at how others were attempting to watch them, and tried their solutions by mounting ISO's to no avail.  I used an alternate method and this works for me.   Using DvdFab (I have version 8) go to the option that says "Blu Ray Ripper" here you will see an assortment of options, I chose "MT2S" copy and paste/ drag the/  your Star Wars Blu Ray folder to the designated area.  Once you have done this step you will see an assortment of files to select with ripping, since the only language I am familiar with is English I leave the settings as is; moreover I am not interested in hearing George Lucas voice overs so I have not selected anything to hear it, and I am presently unaware of which of the files will grant users this ability, I just keep it simple. From this point select the folder you want the rip of your Blu Ray to go to eg. your desktop, documents etc.  After this is complete I have tried to watch these movies without tinkering around to figure out what settings will get it to work on the following:  DivX Plus Player, this seems to crash on me. Windows Media Player, does not work for me.  Cyberlink Powerdvd 10 seems to work, and so does VLC Media which seems to have a much better visual aspect for watching these films.  I hope this helps.
